title: The Swedish historical database project
descriptions:
Here is a 276-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: The Swedish Historical Database Project

This project aims to create a comprehensive and publicly accessible database of highly disaggregated historical data for approximately 2500 Swedish administrative districts over the period 1749-1952. The database will contain around 500,000 observations per variable, covering a wide range of topics including economic activity, political characteristics, vital statistics, occupational structure, education, social statistics, agriculture statistics, and infrastructure investments. A unique aspect of this project is its focus on comprehensive local-level data, providing an international perspective on Sweden's historical development.

The database will build upon Sweden's existing continuous and reliable population data series, which dates back to 1749. This rich dataset will enable researchers to explore various aspects of economic growth, structural transformation, and economic development. The project's research potential is vast, with opportunities to employ empirical identification strategies such as instrumental variables, regression discontinuities, and difference-in-differences estimation.

The project's significance is underscored by its connection to related work, including a paper currently under review at Econometrica. Future research plans include investigating economic development and growth using the database. By making this valuable resource publicly available, the Swedish Historical Database Project will facilitate new insights into Sweden's economic history and contribute to a deeper understanding of the country's development over time.

Here is a 276-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: The Swedish Historical Database Project

This project aims to create a comprehensive and publicly accessible database of highly disaggregated historical data for approximately 2500 Swedish administrative districts from 1749 to 1952. The database will contain over 500,000 observations across eight thematic categories, including economic activity, political characteristics, vital statistics, occupational structure, education, social statistics, agriculture statistics, and infrastructure investments. The project's unique aspects include its comprehensive local-level data and international perspective, providing unprecedented insights into Sweden's historical development.

The database will be built on continuous and reliable population data, which is available from 1749 onwards. This rich dataset will enable researchers to explore various research questions related to economic growth, structural transformation, and economic development. The project's empirical identification strategies will employ instrumental variables, regression discontinuities, and difference-in-differences estimation.

The research potential of this project is vast, and its findings will contribute significantly to the field of economic history. The project builds on previous work, including a paper currently under revision for publication in Econometrica. Future research plans include exploring the determinants of economic development and growth.

By making this database publicly available, the project will facilitate collaboration and knowledge sharing among researchers, policymakers, and the general public. The Swedish Historical Database Project has the potential to become a flagship resource for historical research, providing a unique window into Sweden's past and informing policy decisions that shape its future.

Here is a 276-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: The Swedish Historical Database Project

This project aims to create a comprehensive and publicly accessible database of highly disaggregated historical data for approximately 2500 Swedish administrative districts over the period 1749-1952. The database will contain a wide range of variables, including economic activity, political characteristics, vital statistics, occupational structure, education, social statistics, agriculture statistics, and infrastructure investments, with over 500,000 observations per variable. The unique aspects of this project include its comprehensive local-level data and international perspective, providing a rich foundation for researchers to explore Sweden's economic growth, structural transformation, and economic development during this time period.

The database will be built upon a continuous and reliable population data series starting from 1749, offering an unprecedented opportunity for researchers to apply empirical identification strategies such as instrumental variables, regression discontinuities, and difference-in-differences estimation. The project builds upon related work published in Econometrica, and future research plans include exploring economic development and economic growth. This project has the potential to significantly advance our understanding of Sweden's economic history and provide valuable insights for policymakers and researchers. By making the database publicly available, we aim to facilitate collaboration and stimulate new research in the field of economic history.
